image.altText: Alan Joyce glances to the side during a media conference.

items.synopsis: Embattled Qantas boss Alan Joyce brings his retirement forward by two months after a horror period for the airline.

title.children: Alan Joyce to leave Qantas after tumultuous week to make room for 'renewal'

image.altText: A close-up of NT Chief Minister Natasha Fyles.

items.synopsis: Natasha Fyles's office has released the costings of the nine-day trip after concerns were raised about transparency around ministerial travel.

title.children: NT chief minister's nine-day US trip expected to cost more than $90k

image.altText: A woman lies back in a chair smiling, while someone injects her forehead with a syringe.

items.synopsis: Australia's medical regulator says it is cracking down on cosmetic procedures such as botox and fillers, but those living with the long-term impacts of botched procedures say the focus has come too late.

title.children: Cosmetic surgery crackdown now targeting fillers, botox and other procedures

image.altText: The tail of a Qantas plane in front of a Qantas shed on a tarmac at an airport.

items.synopsis: Qantas boss Alan Joyce has announced he will leave the airline tomorrow, bringing forward his planned retirement by two months. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas boss to leave tomorrow, bringing forward retirement by two months

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The association representing Qantas Group pilots hopes the leadership change at Qantas will provide a 'circuit breaker'. The Australian and International Pilots Association President Captain Tony Lucas says the association looks forward to working with incoming CEO Vanessa Hudson. "There is much work to be done, however we trust that Ms Hudson recognises the power of respecting and valuing all Qantas staff and how that can play a significant role in the renewal of the airline. The Spirit of Australia may be deflated, but it is not defeated and if we all work together, I'm confident Qantas can be great once more."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What the pilots have to say about Qantas

children.content: The association representing Qantas Group pilots hopes the leadership change at Qantas will provide a 'circuit breaker'.
The Australian and International Pilots Association President Captain Tony Lucas says the association looks forward to working with incoming CEO Vanessa Hudson.
"There is much work to be done, however we trust that Ms Hudson recognises the power of respecting and valuing all Qantas staff and how that can play a significant role in the renewal of the airline.
The Spirit of Australia may be deflated, but it is not defeated and if we all work together, I'm confident Qantas can be great once more."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 has opened lower, with US markets closed for Labor Day. The benchmark index dropped -0.5% to 7,283 points at 10:15am AEST. The broader All Ordinaries index also fell -0.5%, to 7486 points. Qantas shares dropped -0.5% on the opening bell, after CEO Alan Joyce announced he will step down from the top job two months early. Vanessa Hudgen will take over as of tomorrow. Meanwhile, the Reserve Bank will meet today to decide the official cash rate. It's expected to stay on hold at 4.1%. Here are some of the top movers at the open: Megaport +1.0% to $12.03 Graincorp +1.0% to $7.30 Boral +0.85 % to $4.76 Lynas Rare Earths +0.7% to $7.31 Auckland International Airport +0.8% to $7.40 And the bottom movers: Lake Resources -3.7% to $0.19 Link Administration -3.1% to $1.33 Northern Star Resources -2.9% $11.36 Paladin Energy -2.5% to $0.91 Johns Lyng Group -2.5% to $6.17 Live updates on the major ASX indices:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower

children.content: The ASX 200 has opened lower, with US markets closed for Labor Day.
The benchmark index dropped -0.5% to 7,283 points at 10:15am AEST.
The broader All Ordinaries index also fell -0.5%, to 7486 points.
Qantas shares dropped -0.5% on the opening bell, after CEO Alan Joyce announced he will step down from the top job two months early.
Vanessa Hudgen will take over as of tomorrow.
Meanwhile, the Reserve Bank will meet today to decide the official cash rate. It's expected to stay on hold at 4.1%.
Here are some of the top movers at the open:
Megaport +1.0% to $12.03
Graincorp +1.0% to $7.30
Boral
Lynas Rare Earths +0.7% to $7.31
Auckland International Airport +0.8% to $7.40
And the bottom movers:
Lake Resources -3.7% to $0.19
Link Administration -3.1% to $1.33
Northern Star Resources -2.9% $11.36
Paladin Energy -2.5% to $0.91
Johns Lyng Group -2.5% to $6.17
Live updates on the major ASX indices:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Tony Burke, says Qantas has been using the labour hire loophole. It comes after the federal government proposed new laws on Monday to close a loophole allowing employers to undercut workers with cheaper labour hire. The new laws would mean companies with more than 15 workers will be forced to pay labour hire staff the same wages as those engaged under enterprise agreements. "Most companies don't use it, but Qantas is a company that has been using the labour hire loophole in a pretty extraordinary way. My objective is to make sure that people at Qantas are paid fairly. I look forward to working with the new CEO Vanessa Hudson. I also look forward to the legislation being passed, because all I want is this: when enterprise agreement rates are agreed to by Qantas, I want them to reflect what's paid at the workplace."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal government calls out Qantas for using labour hire loophole

children.content: The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Tony Burke, says Qantas has been using the labour hire loophole.
It comes after the federal government proposed new laws on Monday to close a loophole allowing employers to undercut workers with cheaper labour hire.
The new laws would mean companies with more than 15 workers will be forced to pay labour hire staff the same wages as those engaged under enterprise agreements.
"Most companies don't use it, but Qantas is a company that has been using the labour hire loophole in a pretty extraordinary way.
My objective is to make sure that people at Qantas are paid fairly. I look forward to working with the new CEO Vanessa Hudson.
I also look forward to the legislation being passed, because all I want is this: when enterprise agreement rates are agreed to by Qantas, I want them to reflect what's paid at the workplace."

image.altText: A composite image shows the three marines in side-by-side images

items.synopsis: Hundreds of defence personnel and other officials have attended a military ceremony to commemorate three marines who died in the MV-22B Osprey aircraft on the Tiwi Islands, ahead of their final voyage home.

title.children: Bodies of US marines killed in Osprey crash farewelled before repatriation flight

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Alan Joyce will leave Qantas after 15 years with $125 million, while the airline's operations have suffered and its reputation has been trashed, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The never-ending spin that protected Alan Joyce and Qantas from reality has started to unravel

image.altText: A seven-month-old boy with scratches on his face and head.

items.synopsis: Seven-month-old Jack had been left alone, unsupervised, in a room when he was beaten by another child. His mother is now pursuing legal action and lawyers say their caseload of injuries sustained at childcare centres is increasing.

title.children: Injuries sustained at childcare centres are on the rise. Experts say there's one common factor

image.altText: Dozens of photos, most arranged on top of each other, on a table

items.synopsis: Three decades after the legendary Queen frontman's death, more than 250 snaps from his personal albums are released publicly for the first time, painting a new picture of a world only his "nearest and dearest" knew until now.

title.children: Freddie Mercury's 'mythology busting' private photos revealed after 30 years

image.altText: a woman's hand holding a newborn baby's feet while in a maternity ward

items.synopsis: An upper house committee into the prevalence of birth trauma in New South Wales, expected to go for several months, received a record 4,000 submissions from the public.

title.children: 'Stop infantilising women': Birth trauma inquiry described as 'me too' moment for mothers in NSW on day one

image.altText: a woman in a white dress with her arms out standing on the sand

items.synopsis: They're integral to Australia's tourism and agriculture industries, but backpacker numbers dropped with travel restrictions during COVID-19.

title.children: Has Australia got its backpackers back? This data suggests so

image.altText: A young Aboriginal woman in a tan suit gestures while speaking on the Q+A set.

items.synopsis: Bundjalung Widubul-Wiabul woman Vanessa Turnbull-Roberts, undecided on the Voice, recalls witnessing non-Indigenous Yes supporters failing to call out racist arguments from the No side, and urges both sides to do better.

title.children: 'Don't be a bystander': Q+A panellist asks non-Indigenous people on both sides of Voice debate to call out racism

image.altText: An Aboriginal flag in the foreground, Parliament House in the background

items.synopsis: The Federal Liberal Party is strongly campaigning against the Voice, but some of its state leaders are at odds with that view.

title.children: Peter Dutton is backing the No vote for the Voice. Here's where other Liberal leaders sit

image.altText: A man wearing a black and red polo shirt stands next to a wire fence with 'polling place' affixed to a banner.

items.synopsis: More people in the Northern Territory are on the electoral roll than ever before, but a lower percentage of them are actually voting, according to the NT Electoral Commission.

title.children: Darwin by-election shows 'significant decline' in voter turnout, sparking concerns ahead of Voice

image.altText: DSC06066_edited

items.synopsis: Two years on from a brain cancer diagnosis, Jade Kurray was showing off her souped-up, hot pink Commodore with hundreds of other motor festival enthusiasts at the popular Red CentreNATS annual street parade.

title.children: Revheads show off cars and burn rubber at ninth 'festival of wheels' in Alice Springs

image.altText: John and Peter Russell  December 1974

items.synopsis: More than 30 years since John Russell's death, his family is still searching for answers about who killed him.

title.children: 'It's still unfinished': Search for answers decades after murder

image.altText: julie inman grant speaks at a press conference

items.synopsis: Stronger age verification processes are needed on sites used by children to help prevent them being coerced into making sexual abuse material, according to the eSafety commissioner.

title.children: Children easily bypassing age verification online, eSafety commissioner says

image.altText: A group of women holding protest signs with strike slogans on them.

items.synopsis: Staff at the stationery and arcade style stores say they are paid cash in hand, below the award wage and are not receiving super.

title.children: Mint My Desk, MillionLife employees take strike action, accusing company of underpaying

image.altText: A still taken from the All Star music video by the American rock band Smash Mouth.

items.synopsis: The All Star singer died in hospice care after entering the final stages of liver failure.

title.children: Smash Mouth's long-time frontman Steve Harwell dies from liver failure at 56

image.altText: A woman with brown curly hair sits on the floor next to a bed made with white linen, kissing her cat on the nose

items.synopsis: Animals, including the ones that live in our homes, can carry all kinds of illnesses. Most of the time it's not a problem, but here's what you should do to avoid getting sick, write Sarah McLean and Enzo Palombo.

title.children: Is it okay to kiss your pet? The risk of animal-borne diseases is small, but real

image.altText: Young girl with a fluffy dog, laying in a white bed with a bandage around her head.

items.synopsis: When Fiona Elsey's mother was going through old mementos she'd kept since her daughter's death, she came across the teen's handwriting unexpectedly. What she read made her cry.

title.children: Fiona died from cancer at 14. Her mum recently found a letter she wrote in the back of a colouring book

image.altText: Peter Dutton in the prime minister's courtyard

items.synopsis: A push for a second referendum by Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has been labelled "sabotage", "idiotic" and "absurd".

title.children: Prime minister calls second referendum push 'sabotage'

image.altText: An older woman at a checkout in a supermarket

items.synopsis: For people who feel lonely, a trip to the supermarket could help — if only the store provided opportunities to chat at the checkout. A Dutch chain has done just that, and customers and staff love it.

title.children: Could supermarket 'slow checkouts' be a cure to rising loneliness?

image.altText: Woman with brown hair shaking a green sheet in a white room.

items.synopsis: For some, clutter is the source of anxiety and distress; for others, poor mental health causes disorganisation. Either way understanding your relationship to mess can be empowering, writes Erika Penney.

title.children: Do you feel overwhelmed by clutter at home? You are not alone

image.altText: Richard Marles playing golf during a visit to Cambodia

items.synopsis: Richard Marles declines to say whether he has ever packed his golf clubs on board any Royal Australian Air Force flights following an opposition attack in parliament over the defence minister's use of VIP transport.

title.children: Opposition targets defence minister over RAAF flights and golf clubs

image.altText: Sandy beach foreshore in early morning. Wind-blown palm trees, empty children's playground & two people on boardwalk in distance

items.synopsis: A West Australian man has been charged after he allegedly attempted to drown his young child at the Dampier Foreshore.

title.children: Father charged after allegedly attempting to drown young child at WA beach

image.altText: Men kneel down while aiming black semi-automatic firearms in a corrugated iron shed.

items.synopsis: A leading opposition MP in Solomon Islands is calling for an independent investigation into a contentious shipment of "replica weapons" brought into the Pacific Island country by China after publicly released US diplomatic cables claimed the guns were likely real.

title.children: 'Were we told the truth?': Chinese 'replica' guns in Solomon Islands likely real, US cable says

image.altText: A man at a microphone in parliament house giving a speech, with several people seated behind him.

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese says aviation is "not a free-for-all" as the opposition pushes for a Senate inquiry into the rejection of Qatar Airways' bid to increase its flights to Australia.

title.children: PM defends rejecting more Qatar flights, says government was not lobbied by Qantas

image.altText: A close up picture of a blonde woman smiling

items.synopsis: The sisters of Perth woman Lynn Cannon say police were caught up with administrative work the night she was killed, which delayed them from attending the scene.

title.children: Administrative tasks delayed police response on night mum was murdered by jealous ex-husband

image.altText: A young boy in a spiderman suit opens his mouth excitedly, facing just off camera.

items.synopsis: The foster mother of missing boy William Tyrrell has pleaded guilty to assaulting a child in her care in incidents that occurred two years ago.

title.children: William Tyrrell foster mother pleads guilty to assaulting a child

image.altText: A man looking at a destroyed vehicle near a road.

items.synopsis: Progress in Ukraine's counteroffensive has been slower than expected, but its forces are building momentum in the country's south, and could be just 15 kilometres away from a major prize.

title.children: Why Ukraine could be just 15km from forcing Putin to make an impossible choice

image.altText: a man wearing a cap looking at the camera and smiling

items.synopsis: The alleged driver involved in a fatal crash involving two siblings in south-west Sydney has posted himself eating a fast food meal allegedly before handing himself in to police.

title.children: Accused driver of crash that killed two siblings allegedly filmed himself eating KFC before going to police

image.altText: Small white button mushrooms growing in soil.

items.synopsis: Supermarkets are telling their mushroom suppliers that sales have decreased by up to 10 per cent in the past few weeks. It comes in the wake of three people dying of suspected death cap mushroom poisoning in Gippsland, Victoria.

title.children: Mushroom sales fall after suspected poisoning at Leongatha lunch

image.altText: Close-up of man

items.synopsis: Ben Roberts-Smith's defamation case against Nine Entertainment was dismissed in June, with the publisher arguing they want the war veteran to pay for the entirety of the proceedings.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith should pay higher share of legal bill for case directed at 'concealing truth'

image.altText: A bright red ship is seen from above breaking a path through sea ice

items.synopsis: An Australian expeditioner with an undisclosed medical condition is evacuated by helicopter from Casey research station and is being brought back to Hobart on the RSV Nuyina.

title.children: Antarctic icebreaker returning after rescue mission to collect expeditioner

image.altText: Giant magpie sculpture beside a gold coin featuring the magpie.

items.synopsis: Just 18 months after swooping into Canberra, a giant magpie is being recognised as one of the nation's top 'big things' on new $1 coins from the Royal Australian Mint.

title.children: Chip-loving magpie swoops in to join Australia's top 'big things' on new collectible coins
